abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome was satisfactory,
            sustainability likely, and institutional development impacts
            were substantial, achieved through satisfactory performances
            by both the Bank and Borrower. Lessons address the
            following: 1) On broad policy issues, conditionalities
            should be very limited in investment lending operations,
            limited to policies that affected the project directly. For
            example, further disbursement to savings and credit
            associations should not have been allowed until there was a
            proper supervisory authority in place. As much as possible,
            further "policy issues" should be integrated into
            alternative documents. 2) On Rural Finance, credit lines
            that are likely to make a large number of small sub-loans
            need considerable delegation of fiduciary responsibilities.
            While eligibility criteria for participating financial
            institutions should be designed during project preparation,
            the project should allow for some flexibility to
            add/subtract financial intermediaries throughout project
            implementation. Loan documents AND budgets should allow this
            flexibility. If the credit line is going to contain a grant
            portion, the project should ensure there is a general
            consensus on the constrain the grant is trying to address,
            so that the project can objectively measure its
            effectiveness. 3) On advisory and business development
            services, the lack of consulting services to help small
            entrepreneurs prepare and implement business plans, was as
            important a constrain to rural finance, as the lack of
            long-term credit on the market.
